description: From Middle French évader, from Latin ēvādō (“I pass or go over; flee”), from ē (“out of, from”) + vādō (“I go; walk”). See also wade.

verbs.description: evade (third-person singular simple present evades, present participle evading, simple past and past participle evaded)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To get away from by cunning; to avoid by using dexterity, subterfuge, address, or ingenuity; to cleverly escape from
examples: to evade the force of an argument

entries.meaning: (transitive) To escape; to slip away; — sometimes with from.
(intransitive) To attempt to escape; to practice artifice or sophistry, for the purpose of eluding.
